block.p: DOWNTOWN BROOKLYN Gardener's Gambit: Peony to King Four

An outdoor living chess garden is the big (1,000 square feet) attraction in the third annual Metrotech Garden Festival, which opens at noon tomorrow. The garden is made up of chess pieces that are rolling planters of formal topiary, flowers and shrubs. International champions and local chess players will compete in matches, and anyone so inclined may call to reserve a time for a match on the big board.
The festival will also include gardening attractions from the Brooklyn Botanic Garden; the Brooklyn Children's Museum; Barnes & Noble; and live noontime jazz on Fridays.

PROSPECT HEIGHTS A Socially Conscious Eye On the Streets of the City

Vivian Cherry began taking pictures on the streets of New York in the 1930's and is still at it. She will speak about her long career this afternoon at the Brooklyn Museum of Art, where a retrospective of her work is on display through Aug. 6.

Some photographs show conditions in the Lower East Side garment industry, Harlem during the Depression, Brooklyn neighborhoods and Times Square (the boys shown below were photographed in 1948). Other selections document the 1950's demolition of the Third Avenue El.

Ms. Cherry was born in 1920 and was one of the few women to do assignments for Life and Sports Illustrated. In the 1940's, she joined the Photo League, a group of photographers dedicated to a progressive social agenda. She will have a dialogue today with Barbara Head Millstein, curator of photography at the museum.

''Vivian Cherry: A Working Street Photographer 1940's-1990's,'' through Aug. 6, Wednesday through Friday, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m., Saturday and Sunday 11 a.m. to 6 p.m.; artist dialogue: today 2 p.m.; Brooklyn Museum of Art, 200 Eastern Parkway, at Washington Avenue; $4; students and people over 65, $2; museum members and children under 12, free; (718) 638-5000.
FLUSHING Good News With a Beat: Roots of R&B on Stage

Martha Wash began singing at 2 in her parents' church and took off from there. Her singing career has been varied, from performing as one of the Weather Girls on the recording ''It's Raining Men'' to working with C & C Music Factory on the pop hit ''Sweat (Everybody Dance Now).''

On Friday night, Miss Wash will lead a five-voice choir and a quartet of instrumentalists in an evening of spirituals and gospel music to conclude the ''Jazz Live'' series at Flushing Town Hall. Miss Wash (below) will bring ''the good news of God'' to the stage in arrangements by Albertina Walker, Alex Bradford, Clara Woortel and others.
Martha Wash Spiritual and Gospel Performance; Friday 8 p.m.; Flushing Town Hall Theater, 137-35 Northern Boulevard at Linden Place; $24; Flushing Council Members, $20; (718) 463-7700, ext. 222.
